Dinwiddie’s teaching interests include cultural studies, African American theater history, dramatic writing, filmmaking and ragtime music. A dramatist …       more >                                             Share       Delicious     Digg This     Reddit        Stumble Upon     Technorati     Twitter        Facebook     Windows Live     Yahoo                 MySpace     Email                   Bread Crumbs                Home          >           Events Calendar          >           I Gotta Right to Sing the Blues: A Hot Jazz Symposium                                                                I Gotta Right to Sing the Blues: A Hot Jazz Symposium   Mar 11, 2014                                   | 7:00 PM-9:00 PM                                   Hot Jazz is experiencing a modern revival. And this renaissance of sorts is at its strongest in our very own New York City, where the music's youthful energy with a modern twist has established a grassroots and markedly social way of engaging with music– a far cry from NYC's formal and austere jazz institutions.    Henry Topper, with the support of the Gallatin Student Resource Fund and the Gallatin Office of Student Life, is proud to bring this new Hot Jazz into the academy for the first time, presenting a lovely, foot-stompingly fun evening of LIVE MUSIC and talks from figures at the forefront of the revival. And it's completely free! This is a truly special opportunity that is not to be missed!     Featuring the Hot Sardines   Talks by Professor Michael Dinwiddie &   Will Friedwald , Jazz Critic at the Wall Street Journal                             Date + Time      Mar 11, 2014                                   | 7:00 PM-9:00 PM              Location      Jerry H. Labowitz Theatre for the Performing Arts                           Open to Public?           yes                              RSVP      RSVP                                                 top of page                               RSVP                                                                                    NYU Gallatin Footer              Gallatin School of Individualized Study     1 Washington Place     New York, NY 10003     (212) 998-7370                   A–Z Index      Directions      Contact Us      Job Opportunities               News      Support Gallatin      Feedback                         Follow us on Facebook      Follow us on Twitter      Follow us on Youtube         Follow us Instagram                 Unless otherwise noted, all content copyright NYU Gallatin. "Allophonic Loom Blues" by Andrew Colarusso, CWP | NYU                         NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                           Creative Writing Program                                                                                                Back to  previous page                Printer Friendly       "Allophonic Loom Blues" by Andrew Colarusso, The Poetics of Cloth Creative Writing Prize Runner-Up      Allophonic Loom Blues                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Moses was taken    From the water    In a swath of colored    Cloth Is the peculiar reason ing I employ to ration alize my desire to have s ex with the woman stand ing in front of me wear ing the thinnest band of a very sheer Cloth.      Let us not get    carried away.    Though I’ve woven myself into her soft bough, I have people to do and things to see. Places to be with memories like thin ribbons or ties that bind—Doc tor, when I was fou r I had this pill ow that I brought wit h me everywhere. A delight so rare of a fabric so fine; she was so fter than anything on t   he face of the  earth. M y folly’s what lost her. I   haven’t been  the S         ame since S aid happening. Have you noticed, Doctor, that in my nervousness I’ve hidden my hands in my sleeves? This sweater, once as white as snow, was given to me by my mother         and coveted bY     my  sister who thrE         atened to throw M e into blue wilderness. InsteA    d she sold  me into slaverY,         and like Jospeh A ccepting his fate, I’ve embraced the savage solitude of loneliness. Boy , she said, Momma’s gone. Earn your  keep .  I  imagine    Moses must have been    an awkward lover.    Take it on the chin ,    said Zipporah, you’ve come     too quickly dear prophet     and you’ve cut     holes in all of my finest     linens . I’ve wondered, too often, about my place in this world. So I’ve found wo(men) to lie with. Churlish par amours granting high pleasures and satin scars that tell stories and little more than that. I am an awkward lover, like Moses. I am wandering, like Moses. Taken from  Mississippi   waters and perhaps, like Moses, I may never see                                                                                                                      This promised sweater, picked from earth with weary fingertips and sewn with sullen sable hands, I’ve had since the age of twelve. Now  stained with chitter ling drippings and two yellow rings of sweat and Mum. I’ve mellow ed since twelve, Doctor, doing word find puzzles and I’ve heard that if you focus hard enough each word has dimension. Tough puzzle though. See here I’ve found: miss— Understand that this fascination I have with pattern and ordered disorder is only an appreciation of nu ance. You’ve mis understood my understand ing that even pho nemes have distinct complexity, weav ing every strand of memory and mythos; like thin ribbons or ties that bind.
